highlights.para: Everybody can participate in the Ubuntu community. Here we discuss how you can work in the wiki, how it is going with the forums and what kind of non-technical work there is, so you can also take part in the creation of this great distribution.

sect2.title: Where do I start if I want to help with Ubuntu?
sect2.para: Ubuntu is a real community project. Here is a list of web-links that will get you started in no time:

itemizedlist.listitem: The first place to go is the wiki.
Subscribe to the mailinglists. Ubuntu is high-traffic, ubuntu-devel is for development related items only.

sect2.title: How do I get an account and contribute to this wiki?
sect2.para: If you wish to contribute to Ubuntu by adding items to this wiki, you must first create an account. To get an account, click on join in the upper right hand corner of the webpage, and follow the directions on that page. If you are returning and wish to log back in, click log in. To edit a page, click on edit.

sect2.title: What international user resources are available?
sect2.para: Please check the local languages page page which is kept updated.

sect2.title: Can I edit the wiki?
sect2.para: Yes - you just have to log in first. Register on the site and log in, or make a new account. There are some areas, such as the seed lists, that should not be changed without confirmation from Matt Zimmerman or Jeff Waugh on the sounder mailing list. We'll put a note on special pages such as these.
The wiki and the web site have the same account information. You are able to add and edit most pages on the website and all in the wiki. Thank you for contributing.

sect2.title: Where are the Ubuntu forums?
sect2.para: We are currently researching different software to run the Ubuntu forums that can also integrate with our mailing lists. We have had some great input from our community with suggestions and we are working on this facet of our community support. As soon as we have them available, we will announce it.
Until then you are invited to join the mailing lists. See the mailing list page.

sect2.title: What non-technical work is there that volunteers can do for Ubuntu?
sect2.para: If you don't code, there's still plenty of ways to get involved with Ubuntu.

itemizedlist.para: It's always surprising what you can find during a normal usage of a pre-release distro that, while nowhere being major bugs, are still worth reporting in the bugzilla for this or future releases. That's the whole point of beta and pre-releases: so that things are tested in thousands of different ways by many different users. What at first applicationear to be a simple bug can turn into a major vulnerability/problem worth patching as soon as possible.
itemizedlist.listitem: Answer questions on mailing lists, forums and IRC
Maintain and tidy up the wiki
Spread the word. Order cds from Shipit - the Ubuntu CD Distribution System and give them away to friends, family, complete strangers.

sect2.title: How do I activate the non-plone zwiki skin?
sect2.para: If you still see the plone skin, do shift-reload or ctrl-f5.
